disease.disease/activity: Anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, antibacterial, cytotoxicity, analgesic, antidiabetic, hepatoprotective
disease.evidence: Table 1: Chemical composition of Carissa carandas L.
The root is antiscorbutic, stomachic and anthelmintic. Decoction of the leaves is useful in early stages of remittent fevers.
The plant has been used as a folk remedy for diabetes. The root is considered tonic and stomachic.
The flowers are good for inflammations, chronic pains in the muscles and the joints, lumbago, headache, and scabies.

disease.disease/activity: Laxative, herpes, syphilis, ulcers, skin diseases
disease.evidence: In addition, the flowers are edible and eaten as fritters, while the heart of the wood is part of a traditional medical preparation taken as a laxative.

disease.disease/activity: Diarrhoea, abdominal complaints, snake and scorpion poisoning, jungle fever, hypertension, headache, scabies
disease.evidence: A decoction is used in the treatment of diarrhoea and abdominal complaints.

compound.compound: Lupeol, Ursolic acid, Beta-Sitosterol, Carinol, Carindone, Carissone
compound.evidence: Table 1: Chemical composition of Carissa carandas L.

compound.compound: Ursolic acid, Daucesterol, Tetrahydroalstonine, Beta-sitosterol, Vindoline

location.evidence: The medicinal plants of Bangladesh South Asian countries have a large number of valuable medicinal plants naturally growing mostly in fragile ecosystems that are predominantly inhabited by rural poor and indigenous community.
